I find rpm better than deb
But I find apt-get better than yum
you are horribly misled.

Debian package manager does not seem to register in the package database when the package was installed, and allows packets to asks question interactively. The latter is a horrible mistake, in my opinion.
a timestamp is not a good way to distinguish between package managers. debian provides a solidly robust system that rpm can't even compare to.
I find that RPM is a lot more robust and comprehensive.
how long have you used ubuntu?
For example, the RPM --qf option, queryformat, offers a lot more tags than Debian's equivalent.
Not long, but long enough to experience the limitations of the debian package manager.
Debian package manager has about 30 fields, I think.
that's quite a good load of FUD you're building
I'm not spreading FUD.
There is no Debian package manager equivalent of RPM's 'INSTALL-DATE'.
how long is 'not very long'?
ten days.
then that doesn't count. when you hit the 1 year mark, then we'll talk. :)

well, i think that you'll find, over time, that even though there's a lack of obvious timestamping, that the system is actually much more robust than RPM.  RPM is nothing more than a patchwork of an originally horribly written package management system.  i used it about a decade ago and it was dreadful... not much has changed in that regard since.  I don't consider 10 days as a good timeframe to judge a package management syste

The timestamping is not a major issue. However, the fact that packages asks questions interactively, is. I would like to seperate configuration from installation, because: (1) during installation, I don't know the answers to those questions (2) I would like to be able to 'walk away' during a big installation/upgrade lasting an hour or more. It is true that ten days is a good timeframe to judge a package management style.

of course, you are entitled to your own opinion, and hopefully you'll enjoy the fact that timestamps are, indeed, made available within the package management system via ls -l /var/lib/dpkg/info/  although I do admit that that is a bit of an issue, and maybe we should take this to #ubuntu-offtopic since the discussion doesn't seem to be helpful to other ubuntu users.
